block.p: Senate Rejects Deadline For Kosovo Withdrawal The Senate voted, 53 to 47, against a measure to set a deadline for withdrawing American troops from Kosovo. The measure was opposed by the Clinton administration and by Governor George W. Bush, although 40 Republicans voted for it.

Senate Rejects Deadline For Kosovo Withdrawal The Senate voted, 53 to 47, against a measure to set a deadline for withdrawing American troops from Kosovo. The measure was opposed by the Clinton administration and by Governor George W. Bush, although 40 Republicans voted for it.

About 20,000 people gathered anew in Belgrade to protest the Serbian government's seizure of the main opposition television station, Studio B, but as they were dispersing, police officers in riot gear charged them. At least 19 people were hurt.

Peru Challenger Pulls Out Alejandro Toledo said he was pulling out of the May 28 runoff election for president, citing concerns about fraud. He asked President Alberto K. Fujimori to delay the vote for three weeks, until international election monitors could test computer systems to ensure an honest vote.

Dominican Wins Presidency A left-leaning populist, Hipolito Mejia, found his path to the presidency cleared of its last obstacle when his opponent from the governing party, Danilo Medina, declined to seek a runoff.
China Trade Debate Heats Up The political jockeying on a China trade bill entered an intensive final stretch as both the Clinton administration and its opponents claimed crucial backing.

U.S. Missile Test Delayed The Pentagon said the next decisive test of a national missile defense system, planned for June 26, had again been delayed by a wiring problem, increasing pressure on the project's managers to meet the Clinton administration's timetable for deciding whether to deploy the system.

Iran Gets World Bank Loans The World Bank, over the objections of the United States, approved its first loans to Iran in seven years: $232 million for a sewage-treatment project in Tehran and for improvements in health care.
Ethiopia Continues Advance Hundreds of thousands of people fled their homes in western Eritrea as Ethiopian troops captured a strategic town, Barentu, and pressed on with their rapid advance.

U.S. Admits Fault in Fire And Pledges Compensation Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt said the government was to blame for the destruction caused by the Los Alamos fire and would compensate victims. His remarks coincided with a report of an inquiry into the Park Service's decision to start the fire to clear underbrush. More than 400 homes have been destroyed.

F.B.I. Memo on Reno The F.B.I. director, Louis J. Freeh, wrote in 1996 that Attorney General Janet Reno and a top deputy should remove themselves from an inquiry into Democratic fund-raising, after the aide was quoted as saying Mrs. Reno could lose her job if the inquiry proceeded, officials said.

F.B.I. Mishandled Lee Case The Federal Bureau of Investigation gravely mishandled its inquiry into Wen Ho Lee, the nuclear scientist suspected of passing secrets to the Chinese government, a Justice Department review concluded.

F.A.A. Orders Bolt Inspections The Federal Aviation Administration ordered airlines flying the Boeing 767 to check the bolts that hold the plane's engines in place after an airline reported finding damage to the bolts.

Move to Abolish Death Penalty The New Hampshire Legislature became the first in the nation to approve a bill banning capital punishment since the Supreme Court allowed executions to resume in 1976. The governor plans to veto it.

Confederate Flag Coming Down The South Carolina legislature agreed to remove the Confederate battle flag from its chambers and the Capitol dome and place it at a nearby memorial to Confederate soldiers.
Talk Show Host Losing Backing Protests by gay rights advocacy groups against Dr. Laura Schlessinger got more results. Procter & Gamble said it will not advertise on her radio or television shows.
Limiting Pastorates to Men Leaders of the Southern Baptist Convention proposed revising the denomination's basic statement of faith to say that the Bible lets only men be church pastors.

Mother and Son Guilty Of Murdering Socialite Sante and Kenneth Kimes, described by prosecutors as a prolific and pitiless con artist team, were convicted of murdering a wealthy woman as part an intricate scheme to steal her Upper East Side townhouse. The body of the 82-year-old victim, Irene Silverman, has never been found.

Disabled Girl Found Dead A 5-year-old Bronx girl with cerebral palsy was found dead in her apartment on Wednesday. A preliminary report noted signs of malnutrition on her 17-pound body. The mother was held for 24 hours and released, pending final autopsy results.

The Speaker Fights a Revolt Sheldon Silver, a Democrat from Manhattan, moved against a challenge to his leadership, retaliating against renegades and enlisting union officials and party leaders to shore up his power base.

Alternative to 'Fight or Flight' Researchers say females often show a different reaction to stress, involving nurturing and seeking support from others rather than aggression or escape. The ''tend and befriend'' response, seen both in humans and animals, may derive from hormonal differences between the sexes.
Yale to Honor a Critic William F. Buckley Jr., a founder of modern American conservatism who in 1951 accused Yale of rejecting God, is returning to campus on Monday, to accept an honorary degree.
A25 Frederick Donald Coggan A former archbishop of Canterbury and the first spiritual head of the Church of England to support the ordination of women, he was 90.

Insurance Fraud Settlement Columbia/HCA Healthcare has agreed in principle to $745 million in civil penalties to resolve part of the government's case into whether its success was partly gained by cheating federal health programs.
Cable TV Dispute Ends Time Warner's chairman said his company and Walt Disney had agreed to end a rancorous dispute over the cable transmission of television networks owned by Disney.
Barrier to Phone Merger The staff of the Justice Department's antitrust division were said to have recommended that the government block the proposed $115 billion merger of WorldCom and Sprint.
European Interest in Nabisco Cadbury Schweppes and Groupe Danone were said to be weighing a joint bid for Nabisco Holdings.
Philadelphia Goes Up, 2-1 The Flyers beat the Devils, 4-2, to take the lead in the four-of-seven-game Eastern playoff finals.
Editorials: The Albany uprising; prosecuting Foday Sankoh; blunders in Los Alamos; a model child care system. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman.
